subject: Re: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required    once
msgSnippet: ... After you load it into a text editor, after you find it on the file system. ... True enough. ... That *is* an annoyance, to be sure. ... I would be
messageBody:
>So said Bill de h√ìra on 4/7/2003 --------------------
>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>>>Can you explain why is 1. better?
>>
>>
>> 1. The data is in the test where I can see it, rather than in a file.
>
>I'm not mad about keeping test files in java code, at least not more
>than one or two of them:
>
> * alt/ctrl-tab means you can see the file if you want to

After you load it into a text editor, after you find it on the file system.

> * changing the file in java code means recompiling

True enough.

> * java doesn't suport multiline strings

That *is* an annoyance, to be sure.

> * What if you have say, 30 files?

I would be surprised to have 30 useful, different programmer-level test cases. If the object is that complex, then maybe it's really more than one object. I'd need a concrete example to be sure.

I always assume we're talking Programmer Tests here, and in that case, the files would rarely need to be that long or that complex.

>> 2. Using data in a file means worrying about where the files are on the
>file system when executing the tests.
>
>Use a relative offset from your project.home

"project.home"? You're assuming Ant, I guess. Ant is widely-accepted, but not universal... yet.

>> 3. What if I need to execute the tests on a file system that doesn't
>understand "g:/myCsvFiles"? (Yes, there are solutions, but none as easy as
>not having to worry about it.)
>
>What if I need to compile the java on a file system that doesn't
>understand "g:/myCsvFiles"?

I don't understand your implied point here.

>> 4. Tests that require the file system are slower.
>
>Not much. And not at all if you're testing through changing/adding
>files and not by changing the code.

I agree "not much", except when there are 1000 tests.

I don't understand the logic of the second sentence.

>> 5. Cleaning up the file system is asynchronous (from what I can tell)
>and unreliable to do in tests that execute at a rate of dozens per second.
>
>If you have to clean up the file system, clean up at the end the
>run; use Ant to rmdir.

When was the last time you tried this? When I did, tearDown() finished before the files were removed, then the next test's setUp() complained that files already existed. That's why I don't like to do it. If the Java File calls were synchronized with the underlying file system, then this wouldn't be a problem.

>> Processing the data is separate from reading/writing the data. This
>implies two separate classes.
>>
>> csvDataProcessor.findDuplicates(new CsvFileReader(fileName));
>> ...
>>
>> This is exactly how XSL transformers work: transforming XML and
>reading/writing XML are separate concerns.
>
>+1

I assume you mean that I scored a point here. :)

Take care.
